newsitem.title: SLOVENIA: Slovenian shares inch higher, seen steady.
newsitem.headline: Slovenian shares inch higher, seen steady.

text.p: Slovenian shares firmed 0.57 percent on Tuesday and traders said prices and volumes would most likely stagnate over the short-term due to a lack of fresh trading incentives.
But some hold out hope for a recovery, fuelled by bottom-fishing with the market at current low levels.
"A lack of demand this last month pushed prices to their current levels. This is a very good time for long-term investors to buy some shares," Robert Rudolf, a trader at brokerage Moja Delnica said.
The SBI index rose 7.24 points or 0.57 percent to 1,281.5.
Turnover slumped to 45.6 million tolars from 80.6 million.
Overall 10 shares rose, five fell and one was unchanged, while 10 were untraded.
Bank SKB was the most actively traded share, firming 4.01 percent to 49,250 tolars on volume of 375 shares for total turnover of 18.2 million tolars.
SKB was traded today for the first time after three days of suspension from trading due to a 30 percent fall of its share Since January 31.
Brokerage Primofin was the biggest gainer, jumping 9.80 percent to 14,000 tolars on volume of two shares.
Ordinary shares of trading company Kovinotehna led the day's decliners, tumbling 10.42 percent to 447 tolars on volume of 300 shares.
